results.title: Frontline
results.creator_credit: David Bradbury, Australian War Memorial, Tasmanian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, British Broadcasting Corporation and ABC
results.brief_description:
An account of the Vietnam War as seen through the camera of the late Australian war correspondent, Neil Davis. David Bradbury’s multi-award winning documentary also examines the ethical issues facing a man in the frontline who is not an active combatant.
Vietnam was a television war, a war said to have been lost in the lounge rooms of middle America, and not on the battlefield. This film explores the conflict, and Davis’ involvement in it, combining his original footage, comments and archival film. It includes the famous, historic footage of the fall of Saigon, which Davis was the only Western journalist to film.

Warning: some scenes may disturb.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Bradbury, Australian War Memorial, Tasmanian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, British Broadcasting Corporation and ABC

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 26]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is situated in the Victorian Alpine Region in the summer months when the only snows are at the very top of the mountains. Wallace focuses on the roads that wind, at times dramatically, through the mountain range as well as the surrounding landscape of trees, rocks and waterways.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’, ‘The Victorian Alps’
00:00:50:00 views from the road and a small old house
00:01:06:00 sign ‘Alpine Road’ with lots of information for the traveller
00:01:25:00 sign ‘You are now entering Mount Hotham Alpine Reserve’
00:01:35:00 looking across a corner of a dirt road high up in the mountains
00:02:22:00 roads, signs and aerials on top of the mountains and a melting snowman
00:02:58:00 brass sundial
00:04:46:00 sign warning to ‘keep to the left of the poles’ and directional sign to ‘Hotham, Diamentina, Harrietville’
00:05:20:00 chair lift pulley station and 1970s style four wheel drive vehicle, a chalet and hamlet
00:05:55:00 a small A-frame chalet or hut
00:06:30:00 views of roads, trees and cars with the mountains in the background
00:07:05:00 two purple swamp hens (common to wetlands or rivers of Eastern Australia)
00:07:50:00 signs ‘Mount Buffalo’ and ‘Eurobin Falls’ followed by views of cascading waters over rocky embankments and cliffs
00:08:30:00 sign ‘Mackeys Lookout’ followed by views out over the valleys below including cars negotiating the tight turns on the roads winding down the mountain
00:09:08:00 sign ‘Rollarson’s Falls’
00:09:35:00 hikers negotiate logs and rocks along the path
00:10:16:00 a long narrow waterfall into a lovely natural rock pool
00:11:00:00 looking out over misty valleys through an old walk bridge
00:13:08:00 a narrow waterfall in a rocky cliffface
00:13:36:00 snow along the sides of the road
00:14:26:00 sign ‘Toownag Gap, Mt Buffalo, Mt Bogong’ and a visitor looking through binoculars from a lookout
00:14:46:00 looking down from a higher vantage spot on a long windy road through the mountains toward a township beyond
00:15:20:00 views of electricity towers across the ranges
00:15:50:00 sign ‘Pretty Valley Branch East Kiewa River’
00:16:11:00 sign ‘rocky Valley Dam’ and scenes around the dam
00:17:05:00 sign ‘Strawberry Saddle’ followed by a mob of emus
00:18:07:00 sign ‘Bundara River’ in the Victorian Alpine Region
00:19:50:00 sign ‘Omeo’, Victoria, followed by an older style cattle truck travelling along a street and the Public Telegraph Office in the township

results.title: Froggie's gone
results.brief_description: This warmly comic documentary is about Beryl from Brunswick whose prized garden frog is stolen from her verandah. Very soon the police and the neighbours are on the trail of the thieves, everyone wanting to do their bit to ensure that Froggie comes back home where he belongs. This acclaimed short film was made by Beryl’s niece as a celebration of community, and is an example of how remembering an episode from your life can make a wonderful piece of film.

results.title: Westbourne Grove
results.brief_description: Combines locational footage with personal reminiscences of growing up in Northcote. This film is an excerpt from ‘Stories from the hidden city’, a project conceived and directed by Bagryana Popov, 2000-2002.

results.title: North
results.creator_credit: Christos Linou, Spiro Economopolous and Christos Tsiolkas
results.brief_description: Collingwood - ‘Hit the North. The north is where they put most of the wogs.’ Utilising excerpts from Christos Tsiolkas’ novel ‘Loaded’, ‘North’ is a lyrical and haunting work about space and place in Melbourne’s inner-city northern suburbs. This short work reveals a history of migrant alienation and regret submerged underneath the asphalt, mortar and concrete of the modern Australian city.

results.title: Beyond LSD: a film for concerned adults and teenagers
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford, Paul Burnford Film Productions and Film Associates

video_links.name: Beyond LSD: a film for concerned adults and teenagers

results.brief_description: This 1960’s film is about the communication gap between two generations: teenagers and young adults on the one hand, and the generation of those over thirty - “the establishment”. The teenagers’ use of LSD and other drugs is only one of the symptoms of this communication gap. A group of parents desperately seek help in order to understand what has gone wrong. The film is an attempt to go “beyond LSD” and is intended to stimulate discussion amongst high school students, college students, teachers and parents. Ample involuntary hilarity can result from viewing this great hysterical/historical document. Starting as a raucous celluloid freak-out, the film presents its square’s-eye view of the “Generation Gap” through the fictive device of a round table of pod people, each alike in their helmet-hair and cat’s eye glasses. The production crew of this film was primarily made up of teenagers and young adults. Music by ‘The Stayns.’ A minor masterpiece of psychedelic cinema.
results.title_for_label: Beyond LSD: a film for concerned adults and teenagers
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Burnford, Paul Burnford Film Productions and Film Associates

results.title: Trip to Mars
results.brief_description: Magical animation details the extraterrestial adventures of hand-drawn harlequin, Koko the clown. Reluctant astronaut Koko inadvertantly launches Mr. Fleischer skyward and the two conclude their supernatural reverie in a ‘taxi-crab’ flung to the rings of Saturn. Koko’s martian odyssey reveals a wealth of unlikely and outlandish natives.

results.title: Wild life in bushland
results.creator_credit: Victorian Government Tourist Bureau and Victorian Railways
results.brief_description: A study of the Healesville Sanctuary for Australian native animals and birds that was originally established by Sir Colin Mackenzie in 1921 to protect injured and endangered native animals in a natural bush environment. Almost 50 Australian animals are captured on film including platypus, lyrebirds and a fighting kangaroo. Commentary: Ray Chapman. Photographed and edited by A. M. Fairfoul. Produced with the collaboration of the sanctuary’s director, David H. Fleay.

results.title: reLOCATED - Mr and Mrs Kemp
results.brief_description: Kensington - this short film is created from a series of photographs and interviews with Mr and Mrs Kemp, residents of the Kensington Public Housing estate for 38 years. ‘reLOCATED’ documents the lives of residents from the estate who were moved when the estate was redeveloped. It is a visual record of how places contain the memories of people’s lives as well as a fantastic example of how you can use non-video media to make a powerful moving image story.

results.title: Supervising women workers
results.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow and United States. Office of Education
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems in Supervision”.
A factory foreman discusses with the supervisor the “problem” of supervising women workers in his department. The fact is brought out that the same rules apply in supervising both men and women; but, “as women often have not had as much industrial experience as men, and in most cases have more home responsibilities than men, these factors must be taken into account”. Note that this film was made in 1944 and uses such terms as “breaking in” the female workers and “the eternal feminine”. Interesting from a historical point of view.
